children.subject:
Yes, I believe the best way to direct complaints is to admit we have a lot of problems and talk with students to figure out potentially better solutions.

I remembered Chancellor said "We must assure that every student thrives at Berkeley, not just survives." in her email. If there are people complaining, there are reasons behind it. It must be true that some of them are not thriving. 

One of my best friends told me he was considering transferring out Berkeley two weeks ago. I was shocked at that time because he was doing well in his classes and was trying to make use of campus resources. This should not happen on students who are in the No. 1 public university in the world.

history.content:
For enrollment, this is very clear: the chancellor and provost have ultimate accountability, since in the Berkeley system, they essentially control *all* the funding on the teaching side. (Funding does not follow student enrollments or majors.)

To meet demand, central campus does not provide sufficient TA funding, does not provide sufficient access to rooms for student-facing contact like office hours or HW parties, does not provide *any* rooms for internal meetings (say TA meetings, grading meetings, or course staff meetings of any kind) to support courses, does not provide sufficient funding for readers and tutors, and essentially does not provide *any* funding for staff support for instructors of courses, and provides neither funding nor staff for the development of software tools to help in course operations. Campus provides essentially *no* funding or support for any work done to make courses more supportive or inclusive. Nor are there even any robust processes by which faculty can easily request such support from campus in the amounts required for courses at EECS scale. The fact that any of this functions at all is largely due to the amazing levels of dedication of EECS staff, TAs and Readers and Tutors who go far above and beyond the call of duty, and faculty who put in way more effort than anyone could reasonably expect --- just because all these people love and care about students so much. 

Students can and should look for themselves to see exactly how the campus budget (of billions of dollars) is spent. It is illustrative to compare the total amount spent on faculty, postdocs, TAs and research assistants, etc. against the total amount spent on people's salaries across campus. If you want to drill down and look at the other numbers at the level of colleges, libraries, and departmental staff, you will see that that is not where the money is being spent either. Students can decide for themselves if they value the rest of the services (not teaching, not research, not libraries, not internet, not staff support from EECS or college staff) in the same proportion that their tuition and tax dollars are being spent on them. Faculty might have our own opinions, but you are all reasonably independent adults. Think for yourselves about what you would value more?

Make lists of services that you get from central campus as compared to from departments, faculty, and TAs. What do you value more or less? Share what you think the priorities should be with the chancellor and provost. (But be responsible stewards --- think about future generations of students and citizens and their interests as well as yours. Presumably, you want a better stronger more effective Berkeley for both yourselves and those who come after you.)

The chancellor presumably hears from people who demand more services from central campus. That is presumably why central campus spends money on that. Does she hear from you to fund TAs? To give space for office hours and homework parties? 

Engineers should never just complain or lament. That is not the spirit of being an engineer. Engineers listen and look at both the big picture and the details. Engineers understand that they don't understand everything. Engineers try to identify what is wrong and communicate both the problem and potential solutions. And engineers work together to make this happen. They provide tools to help each other. Especially when this can be done in a win/win way. 

Faculty and staff do their parts. Students have to do theirs too. We are all in this together.

children.subject:
I couldn't find much on this either; however, there was a post by Chancellor Christ addressing the tuition increase and need for increased teaching resources, specifically within the EECS department:

http://news.berkeley.edu/2018/01/24/chancellor-carol-christ-tuition-increases-a-last-but-necessary-resort-to-campus-budget-woes/

"Let me provide a concrete example of what this means. The average lower division lecture size in our department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science has gone from 65 students in 2011-12 to 227 in 2016-17, the number of students taught from 7,986 to 15,470. If the faculty had grown at the same rate as teaching workload, we would have added over 50 new computer science faculty. The tuition increase would enable us to address these issues of overcrowding and unmet demand for courses. I’ve been troubled by the sheer numbers of students who have come to me with questions about basic instructional needs. They ask me to add more sections and reduce the size of classes. A tuition increase directly funds core instruction and would alleviate these pressures that students face. Freezing tuition—not allowing modest increases—can actually add to the cost of attendance. Enrollment growth is having the undesired effect of making it harder for many students to get the courses they need, in the sequence they need to take them, in a timely fashion. We lengthen the time to degree, adding to individual students’ cost of attendance, because they wind up paying more semesters of tuition and more months of high Bay Area housing costs."
You can see the salaries of public employees here: https://ucannualwage.ucop.edu/wage/

In case anyone is interested in analyzing this data in Excel, I've downloaded it into a 30MB spreadsheet.

Note that there are about 600 different position titles, though, so it's going to be fun categorizing them.
Also here's a CSV (too large for Google Sheets).

"Students can and should look for themselves to see exactly how the campus budget (of billions of dollars) is spent." Is there a specific public resource that we can look at with a detailed budget breakdown? When I google "UC Berkeley budget" I mostly get news articles and slides about where funding is coming from.

The Chancellor has office hours you can attend ("Appointments are open to individuals or groups of up to four currently registered undergraduate or graduate students, and first-time registrants are given priority.") The office hours are full for the fall semester, but it says you should be able to book them again in January: https://chancellor.berkeley.edu/office-hours-chancellor-christ

I'm sure there is another outlet for you to get your message across to her before January; perhaps Anant would have more ideas on this.

Regarding course enrollment, there seems to be a campus wide steering committee / working group on "identifying optimal enrollment levels". There is a list of faculty members on the committee here (https://strategicplan.berkeley.edu/structure/#); it is not clear how you would be able to provide feedback other than perhaps emailing the chair directly.
Thank you!

There was also a reddit AMA with the Chancellor two weeks ago; looks like you missed it, but I'm sure there will be another: https://www.reddit.com/r/berkeley/comments/9mhs3p/i_am_carol_christ_chancellor_of_uc_berkeley_ask/?author=carolchrist

Rachel, good links. It is useful to note that nobody from the largest department (EECS) is on the optimal enrollments working group. 

Many hands make light work. The question is whether students in our various majors, who have experience with software tools, doing analysis, and in running large collaborative operations, can step up to the job. It's not for us faculty to say how students choose to mobilize. Our power also ties our hands because we respect the independence, creativity, and political autonomy of our students.
Thanks for the link and thanks all faculty members in EECS department for your efforts

More concretely, there is a CFO shared google folder that displays budget and other related expense. There is not an EECS specific one that I can find but there is one for the COE. It is interesting to note that we are operating at a surplus according to the spreadsheet. At the end of the day it just comes down to the fact that most people care enough to complain but not to do something. It would be trival to organize a protest or some other outcry method but honestly how many people do you think would show up?

Can I take a couple seconds to suggest you guys don't try to organize a protest even if people do show up? Protesting is what you do when (shall we call it) 'diplomacy' has failed, not when you're merely upset about something. To my knowledge the EECS student body [and maybe the larger student body] has put little genuine effort toward diplomacy with campus on the issue. (I'm a grad student who's been here the past 8 years, half of it as an undergrad.)

More generally, Berkeley is too protest-happy and it has diminished the significance/meanning of all the protests down to... very little. It's like antibacterial medicine. It stops being effective when you use it all the time.

I would organize a group that's willing to engage in dialog, gather irrefutable data proving our point that money is being spent in less-than-sensible ways (the plot below seems like an excellent starting point but I would dig deeper so they can't just say "oh it's more complicated than that"), then when I'm ready, on behalf of everyone involved, email a campus administrator (the Chancellor directly if need be) a respectful but firm letter asking whom/where we can sit down and analyze in detail information we have gathered about campus spending. If you don't think the data is irrefutable then first debate it amongst yourselves to make it such. This will not happen over a weekend. It can take weeks/months of work, potentially an entire semester even. You can't re-demand a second and third meeting just because you didn't do your due diligence the first time.

This is a good idea. And, when I said "Is there any way to let Chacellor hear us?" I was not suggesting a protest. I really hope to find a way to do what you are suggesting here, in a rational and diplomatic way. I also think OP is not suggesting a protest, but instead just so frustrated that want to find someone to talk about the issue.

Is there any way to let Chacellor hear us? I am grateful to everyone in the department who helped us a lot. We don't want to blame anyone who are kind and tried their best but just looking for a path to solutions.   

If improvements can be made on upper divs, I (and many students I believe) would be very willing to volunteer to be "all these people love and care about students so much". However, under enrollment pressure, which means many of us cannot enroll in courses we really need, many of us need to work much harder and have other commitments to remain competitive to get intern/research as those who are fortunate enough to get enrolled in these courses, and those in other schools who have no problem with enrolling in useful courses.

Wow, this is actually absurd. Does anyone know if Chancellor Christ has been asked/ has made a statement about this statistic? I love the faculty here, but sometimes this administration makes me regret choosing to come to this school and give them my money. What a shame.
When there's government money to go around, it gets, well, milked. Happens in other sectors too.
It's a shame they don't use this money to hire more professors

Based on what Chancellor Christ has said about this issue in the AMA/speech linked on other posts, she also seems to frame this issue as a lack of faculty. However, what stands out to me about Professor Sahai's answer is that it appears to the lack of everything supporting faculty (rooms, staff/TA budget etc.) that is causing enrollment problems at the upper division level.

Perhaps we should focus on staff & room issues given that it is possible they are currently overlooked by administration.

EDIT: There was one remark made by the Chancellor in the AMA that I missed in my initial read: "I think the investments that we’ve made in increasing GIS and lecturer funding (which we’ve increased every year) is less visible than some of the investments we’ve made in issues with higher political profiles."

So room reservation seems to be the one issue here that isn't talked about.
Professor Rao's op ed seems relevant http://www.dailycal.org/2017/09/15/uc-berkeleys-drop-ranking-tied-administrative-spending/

"Total wages (which includes benefits) are roughly $1.6 billion at Berkeley. So where does the rest of that compensation go? Academic senate faculty wages and benefits consume just 18 percent of total compensation expense. The hole in the bucket is not small!

In light of the rise of UCLA to the No. 1 public university club, it is worth noting that UCLA’s administration appears to consume a significantly smaller slice of their pie, according to federal data. If UC Berkeley were as efficient as UCLA, we could easily add 100 faculty to campus today … several times over."

^From the LA Times

The Economist says Berkeley has 175 "diversity officials"

https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2018/05/08/the-rise-of-universities-diversity-bureaucrats

history.content: It seems like every semester the state of enrollment gets worse and worse. Classes that were overenrolled in previous semesters have the same number of (or less) seats, and even declared seniors and juniors can't take the classes they want in their own department. The advisors on this page have reiterated multiple times that they do not have say over these things, so who does? Who can I give feedback to so that hopefully these things get fixed in the future?
history.subject: Directing Concerns/Complaints about enrollment
